front.title: Using JSON Web Encryption (JWE) for Protecting JSON Web Key (JWK) Objects

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Say something about why wrapping keys is worthwhile.
Say something about why re-using JWE semantics is worthwhile.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: This document inherits JSON Web Algorithms (JWA)-related terminology from , JSON Web Encryption (JWE)-related terminology from , JSON Web Key (JWK)-related terminology from , and password-based cryptography-related terminology from . Security-related terms are to be understood in the sense defined in .
The capitalized key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: Protecting Keys
section.t:
To protect a key, the key holder performs the following steps:
Converts the JWK object to a UTF-8 encoded string (K'). Performs the message encryption steps from to generate the JWE header H, JWE Encrypted Key E, JWE Initialization Vector IV, JWE Ciphertext C, and JWE Integrity Value I, using the following inputs:
The 'alg' property set to the intented key encryption algorithm (e.g. "RSA-OAEP", or "PBES2-HS512+A256KW" from below). Keying material appropriate for the selected key encryption algorithm (e.g. private key for "RSA-OAEP", or shared password, salt, and iteration count for "PBES2-HS512+A256KW"). The 'enc' property set to the intended content encryption algorithm (e.g. "A256GCM" or "A256CBC+HS512"). Keying material appropriate for the selected content encryption algorithm (e.g. Content Encryption Key and Initialization Vector). K' as the plaintext content to encrypt.
Serializes to the appriopriate format for exchange, such as the Compact Serialization documented in .

section.title: Private Key Example
section.t: NOTE: unless otherwise indiciated, all line breaks are included for readability.

The key holder begins with the representation of the private key (here using a formatted RSA private key):

The key holder uses the following inputs:
JWE Header
{ "alg":"PBES2-HS256+A128KW", "enc":"A128CBC+HS256", "jwk":{ "kty":"PBKDF2", "salt":"2WCTcJZ1Rvd_CJuJripQ1w", "itrs":4096 } }
Password:
Thus from my lips, by yours, my sin is purged.
Content Master Key (encoded as base64url per )
1ICvnpc3zPRNS7JoJ9bnJ929eX7EnRwmc0CHNOF1zKc
Initialization Vector (encoded as base64url per ):
B9BVK3hIsEu9zUOWjKeOSg

section.title: Using Password-Based Cryptography
section.t: There are often times when a key is exchanged through immediate human interaction. To help facilitate such exchanges, a number of password-based cryptography schemes utilizing are defined to supplement the key format, agreement, and encryption algorithms from .

section.title: PBKDF2 Key Type
section.t: The "PBKDF2" type is used to contain the parameters necessary to derive a cipher key from a password. The following parameters are defined:

section.title: 'slt' Parameter
section.t: The REQUIRED "slt" parameter contains the PBKDF2 salt value (S), as a base64url encoded string. This value SHOULD NOT be the empty string "".

section.title: 'its' Parameter
section.t: The REQUIRED "its" parameter contains the PBKDF2 iteration count (c), as an integer. This value MUST NOT be less than 1, as per .

section.title: 'dkl' Parameter
section.t: The RECOMMENDED "dkl" parameter contains the PBKDF2 derived-key octet length (dkLen), as an integer. This parameter MAY be omitted (and MUST be ignored) when the key encryption algorithm requires a specific key length.

section.title: PBKDF2 Key Agreement Algorithms
section.t: The "PBKDF2-HS256" and "PBKDF2-HS512" key agreement algorithms are used to produce a JWE Content Master Key from a user-supplied password, as per the PBKDF2 key derivation function from section 5.1 of . The "PBKDF2-HS256" algorithm uses "HMAC-SHA256" for the psuedo-random function (PRF), while the "PBKDF2-HS512" algorithm uses "HMAC-SHA512" for the PRF.

The derived key length (dkLen) SHOULD be specified in the applicable "PBKDF2" JWK object, and if specified MUST be equal to the size in octets for the content encryption algorithm. However, implementations MAY assume a value necessary for generating a JWE Content Master Key appropriate for desired the content encryption algorithm, ignoring the value of the "dkl" parameter.

section.title: PBES2 Key Encryption Algorithms
section.t: The "PBES2-HS256+A128KW" and "PBES2-HS512+A256KW" key encryption algorithms are used to encrypt a JWE Content Master Key using a user-supplied password to derive the key encryption key. These algorithms combine PBKDF2 with a key wrapping algorithm to encrypt the JWE Content Master Key according to PBES2 from section 6.2 of .
The "PBES2-HS256+A128KW" algorithm uses a dervied key length of 16 octets, while "PBES2-HS512+A256KW" uses a derived key length of 32 octets.

section.title: Re-using Keying Material
section.t: It is NOT RECOMMENDED to re-use all of the same keying material (Key Encryption Key, Content Master Key, Initialization Vector, etc) to protect multiple JWK objects.

section.title: Storing Protected Keys
section.t: Depending on the application, a protected JWK could be stored for an extended duration.

section.title: Using Passwords
section.t: While convenient for end users, passwords have many drawbacks, such as the limited range of values usable on typical input devices (e.g. keyboards). To help mitigate these limitations, this document applies principals from to derive cryptographic keys from user-supplied passwords.

front.title: Key words for use in RFCs to Indicate Requirement Levels

abstract.t: In many standards track documents several words are used to signify the requirements in the specification. These words are often capitalized. This document defines these words as they should be interpreted in IETF documents. Authors who follow these guidelines should incorporate this phrase near the beginning of their document: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.
Note that the force of these words is modified by the requirement level of the document in which they are used.

This memo represents a republication of PKCS #5 v2.0 from RSA Laboratories' Public-Key Cryptography Standards (PKCS) series, and change control is retained within the PKCS process. The body of this document, except for the security considerations section, is taken directly from that specification.

front.title: The Base16, Base32, and Base64 Data Encodings

abstract.t: This document describes the commonly used base 64, base 32, and base 16 encoding schemes. It also discusses the use of line-feeds in encoded data, use of padding in encoded data, use of non-alphabet characters in encoded data, use of different encoding alphabets, and canonical encodings. [STANDARDS TRACK]

This Glossary provides definitions, abbreviations, and explanations of terminology for information system security. The 334 pages of entries offer recommendations to improve the comprehensibility of written material that is generated in the Internet Standards Process (RFC 2026). The recommendations follow the principles that such writing should (a) use the same term or definition whenever the same concept is mentioned; (b) use terms in their plainest, dictionary sense; (c) use terms that are already well-established in open publications; and (d) avoid terms that either favor a particular vendor or favor a particular technology or mechanism over other, competing techniques that already exist or could be developed. This memo provides information for the Internet community.

front.title: Public-Key Cryptography Standards (PKCS) #1: RSA Cryptography Specifications Version 2.1

abstract.t: This memo represents a republication of PKCS #1 v2.1 from RSA Laboratories' Public-Key Cryptography Standards (PKCS) series, and change control is retained within the PKCS process. The body of this document is taken directly from the PKCS #1 v2.1 document, with certain corrections made during the publication process.
